Recommendation.Description: Check the vCenter Server Health. To check for further details on any issues, use vSphere Client monitoring and alarms, vCenter Server Appliance Management Interface, and Skyline Health checks for vSphere.
Check and resolve alerts on ESXi host. To check for further details on any issues, use vSphere Client monitoring and alarms, and Skyline Health checks for vSphere.
Verify that the SCSI controller is VMware certified. See VMware KB 2109871. To check for further details on any issues, use Skyline Health checks for vSphere.

If a password expires, you must manually reset the password in the respective SDDC component. To synchronize the new password in SDDC Manager, you must remediate the component password. See "Remediate Passwords" in the VMware Cloud Foundation Administration guide.
To check the DNS configuration, use the 'nslookup' or 'dig' commands. If the issue persists, please contact VMware Global Support.
To troubleshoot an unidentified NVMe device, see VMware  KB 85782. To check for further details on any issues, use Skyline Health checks for vSphere.
To check for further details on issues, use vSphere Client monitoring and alarms.
Ensure that Forward and Reverse DNS records are configured correctly.

To manually reset SDDC component passwords, please see the related VMware documentation and VMware Knowledge Base articles for respective components. 
- For SDDC Manager, see here.
- For vCenter Server, see  here.
- For NSX Manager, see  here.
- For vRealize Suite Lifecycle Manager, see  here.
- For vRealize Operations, see here.
- For vRealize Automation, see here.
- For vRealize Log Insight, see here.
Check if there are any core dumps on the ESXi host generated as a result of a failure.

Verify if the vSAN disk group type (All-Flash or Hybrid) is certified for the used SCSI controller in the VMware Compatibility Guide.  See VMware vSAN HCL and VMware  KB 2149404. To check for further details on any issues, use Skyline Health checks for vSphere.

Verify that installed driver for the storage I/O controller is supported in the corresponding ESXi version. See VMware  KB 2109263. To check for further details on any issues, use Skyline Health checks for vSphere.
Verify that the controller firmware is VMware certified. See VMware KB 2149405. To check for further details on any issues, use Skyline Health checks for vSphere.

To prevent SDDC component passwords from expiring, see "Password Management" in the VMware Cloud Foundation Administration guide. 
VMware recommends that you use SDDC Manager for password rotation. By using SDDC Manager, you can schedule automatic password rotation for accounts managed by SDDC Manager.
Check the vCenter Server services status by using the vCenter Server Appliance Management Interface at https://appliance-IP-address-or-FQDN:5480 and resolve any issues.

Avoid entering hosts in maintenance mode and simultaneous migration of multiple virtual machines by using vMotions since this can generate a lot of network traffic and can lead to resource depletion. 
To evaluate the status of objects that are being resynchronized,  monitor the in-progress resynchronization tasks in vSphere Client.

Verify that the installed driver is supported for the corresponding controller in the current ESXi version. See VMware KB 2109262. To check for further details on any issues, use Skyline Health checks for vSphere.

Verify that the same NTP server(s) are configured and reachable across all VMware Cloud Foundation SDDC components. Verify that the NTP service is running on each virtual machine. If the NTP server(s) are not configure correctly or operational, update the NTP server configuration across SDDC components. See "Update NTP Server Configuration" in the VMware Cloud Foundation Administration guide.
Check and remediate the virtual machine's storage policy compliance in vSphere Client.
Verify that the NVMe device is VMware certified. See VMware KB 85852. To check for further details on any issues, use Skyline Health checks for vSphere.
Verify that NSX services are running and that SDDC Manager can reach the NSX Manager virtual machine(s) on port 443.
To update the DNS server configuration across SDDC components, see "Update DNS Server Configuration" in the VMware Cloud Foundation Administration guide.

Check the status of the SDDC Manager services by using the SDDC Manager Supportability and Serviceability (SoS) utility and resolve any issues. See "Supportability and Serviceability (SoS) Utility" in the VMware Cloud Foundation Administration guide.
Troubleshoot virtual machine TCP/IP connectivity. See VMware KB 1007842.
To prevent SDDC component certificates from expiring, see "Certificate Management" in the VMware Cloud Foundation Administration guide.
Verify that ESXi services are running and that SDDC Manager can reach the ESXi host on port 443.
To remove expired or unused SDDC component certificates, see "Remove Old or Unused Certificates" in the VMware Cloud Foundation Administration guide.
